cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.DC, cs.SI, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with a coordination problem in a network, which involves exchanging messages and perfect coordination with zero error. This suggests that the paper may belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) or Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-categories. Additionally, the paper discusses connections with graph entropy, rate distortion theory, and mutual information, which are all topics within the Information Theory sub-category. The paper also mentions the distributed computation problem, which falls under the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) sub-category. Furthermore, the paper discusses a notion of set coordination, which may be related to Social and Information Networks (cs.SI) or Machine Learning (cs.LG) sub-categories. Overall, the most likely sub-categories are cs.IT and cs.NI, followed by cs.DC, cs.SI, and cs.LG.
